identificationModule.briefTitle: Cranial Ultrasound for Prehospital ICH Diagnosis
identificationModule.officialTitle: Cranial Ultrasound for Prehospital ICH Diagnosis (CUPID_EMS)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: To evaluate the feasibility of Emergency Medical System (EMS)-performed cPOCUS in the field for diagnosis of acute Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH)
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: With the over-arching goal of achieving early diagnosis of Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) with cPOCUS, this study hypothesizes that (a) Emergency Medical System (EMS) personnel can competently perform cPOCUS in the field in a timely fashion in a large majority of stroke patients; (b) acquired POCUS images can be successfully and securely transmitted for a remote physician interpretation in a timely manner; and (c) cPOCUS will have a greater sensitivity and specificity than clinical scores as a screening tool for ICH identification in pre-hospital settings.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: Any patient deemed to have a stroke like presentation or possibility of brain hemorrhage in the clinical judgement of the EMS provider and a decision to transfer the patient to the nearest ED for further evaluation has been made

armGroups.label: Cranial Point of Care Ultrasound
armGroups.description: Cranial ultrasound involves 2-dimensional B mode imaging of the brain parenchyma in the axial plane
interventionNames: Procedure: Cranial Point of Care Ultrasound

interventions.name: Cranial Point of Care Ultrasound
interventions.description: Cranial ultrasound involves 2-dimensional B mode imaging of the brain parenchyma in the axial plane using a 1-2 MHz probe through the thin temporal bone. Upload of cPOCUS images will occur over DICOM® based Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) compliant platforms accessible via Cloud. Currently all handheld machines use Tricefy® or their own cloud based remote image access application.

primaryOutcomes.description: cPOCUS will be attempted and performed on about 1000 patients over 12 months by 30 EMS providers

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Any patient deemed to have a stroke like presentation or possibility of brain hemorrhage in the clinical judgement of the Emergency Medical Services (EMS) provider and a decision to transfer the patient to the nearest Emergency Department (ED) for further evaluation has been made will be eligible for the study
* 18 years old or older
* transfer initiated by EMS to the ED for further evaluation
* performing ultrasound will not interfere with the care or triage as part of routine care

Exclusion Criteria:

* less than 18 years old
* incarcerate patients
* penetrating cranial/head trauma or scalp wound
* any patient where performing ultrasound will interfere with the care
* patients who decide not to be transported to ED

ipdSharingStatementModule.description: Individual participant data that underlie the results reported in this article after deidentification (text, tables, figures, and appendices)
ipdSharingStatementModule.timeFrame: Beginning 3 months and ending 5 years following article publication
ipdSharingStatementModule.accessCriteria: Researchers who provide a methodologically sound proposal
